channel.title: Mouse Movements like RID bot
channel.description: I was wondering if anyone could help me recreate the mousemovements like those of Robotzindisguise mage arena bot? if anyone has used the bot they can see it has very human like and smooth movements. The mouse changes speed and does not travel on the same path each time. I googled it but came up with nothing...can anyone help me with this?

item.title: Mouse Movements like RID bot
item.dc:creator: @BAsh BAsh
item.description:
@BAsh wrote:

fitts law has got to do with how long it takes to get to a point. If it is on the edge of the screen it is a lot quicker because the edge acts as a hard limit.

Read full topic

item.title: Mouse Movements like RID bot
item.dc:creator: @BAsh BAsh
item.description:
@BAsh wrote:

It doesn’t address the issue of the path itself. While there was a method in Arga it was really shit as it was really loopy. I’m looking for one that allows the destination to be changed mid movement allowing the mouse to track a character for example.

Read full topic

item.title: Mouse Movements like RID bot
item.dc:creator: @ilyaostr9 io9
item.description:
@ilyaostr9 wrote:

By BenLand100

[code=java]public class HumanMouseMovement {

public HumanMouseMovement() { }

public static long fittsLaw(double targetDist, double targetWidth, double reactTime, double timePerBit) {
	return (long)(reactTime + timePerBit * (Math.log10(targetDist / targetWidth + 1.0D) / Math.log10(2D)));
}

public static long hicksLaw(double options, double timePerBit) {
	return (long)(timePerBit * (Math.log10(options + 1.0D) / Math.log10(2D)));
}

public static long reactionExpected(int options, double focus, double activity) {
	double reaction = hicksLaw(options, 125D + 50D * Math.random());
	return fittsLaw(activity, focus, reaction, 125D + 50D * Math.random());
}

public static long reactionRandom(double focus, double work) {
	double reaction = hicksLaw(100D * work, 125D + 50D * Math.random());
	return fittsLaw(work, 1.0D - focus, reaction, 125D + 50D * Math.random());
}

public static long hesitance(double focus, double activity) {
	return fittsLaw(activity, focus, 25D + 25D * Math.random(), 50D + 50D * Math.random());
}

}[/code]

Read full topic
